column1: Hyperaldosteronism is a disorder in which the adrenal gland releases too much of the hormone aldosterone into the blood.
Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to a problem of the adrenal glands themselves, which causes them to release too much aldosterone.
In contrast, with secondary hyperaldosteronism, a problem elsewhere in the body causes the adrenal glands to release too much aldosterone.
Most cases of primary hyperaldosteronism are caused by a noncancerous (benign) tumor of the adrenal gland.

Primary and secondary hyperaldosteronism have common symptoms, including: - High blood pressure - High level of calcium in the blood - Fatigue - Headache - Muscle weakness - Numbness - Paralysis that comes and goes

Tests that may be ordered to diagnose hyperaldosteronism include: - Abdominal CT scan - ECG - Plasma aldosterone level - Plasma renin activity - Serum potassium level - Urinary aldosterone A procedure to insert a catheter into the veins of the adrenal glands may need to be done.
Primary hyperaldosteronism caused by an adrenal gland tumor is usually treated with surgery.
Even after surgery, some people still have high blood pressure and need to take medicine.

Medicines to treat hyperaldosteronism include: - Drugs that block the action of aldosterone - Diuretics (water pills), which help manage fluid buildup in the body Secondary hyperaldosteronism is treated with medicines (as described above) and limiting salt intake.
Primary hyperaldosteronism can cause very high blood pressure, which can damage many organs, including the eyes, kidneys, heart and brain.
Impotence and gynecomastia (enlarged breasts in men) may occur with long-term use of medicines.
